Rationale
This module has been developed as part of the new Msc in Advanced Bioscience Techniques and research facility management

Admin

Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Replace Instances with Code
BIOS772
Notes
The module will run in the second semester of the MSc Advanced Bioscience Techniques and Research Facility Management programme. All students enrolled on the MSc programme will be required to complete the module. To develop the module a workshop was held including the module coordinator, programme lead, the module teaching staff and members (academic leads and facility managers) representing the range of Shared Research Facilities at the University of Liverpool. The workshop provided a platform to exchange ideas on module content, modes of delivery and assessments methods and criteria that were developed into the module syllabus and specifications by the module coordinator and teaching team.

Overview

Overview
This MSc Module Core Facility Operation and Management Module will introduce students to a multitude of different aspects of running a core scientific facility including the operation and management of a core facility, the roles and responsibilities of the team members, management of finances, understanding your customers and developing networks. Students will undertake a series of lectures, tutorials, workshops including visits and tours of the research facilities and self-directed study and complete two assessments, one to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources and the second to develop a proposal for a new core facility.
Educational Aims
To provide students with the opportunity to apply directed and independent learning to develop a holistic understanding of the role and operation of a core research facility that can be applied in their own scientific discipline and/or workplace.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The 15-credit MSc Core Facility Operation and Management Module will introduce students to a multitude of different aspects of running a core scientific facility including the operation and management of a core facility, the roles and responsibilities of the team members, management of finances, and understanding your customers and developing networks. Students will undertake a series of lectures, tutorials, workshops including visits and tours of the Liverpool shared research facilities and self-directed study to complete the module. Students will complete two assessments (1) to produce a written report to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources and (2) to produce a written report and delivery a presentation to develop a new core facility. The module will enable students to develop an understanding of the operation and management of a core research facility and provide students with an opportunity to present their work in oral and written formats. The module takes place during the second semester.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will be delivered by a combination of lectures, workshops and self-directed learning supported by resources provided on Canvas. The syllabus will include the following elements:
(1)Introduction to core scientific facility and operation including the University of Liverpool Shared Research Facilities, University of Liverpool and UKRI strategies and implications for scientific research facilities
(2)Roles and responsibilities within a core scientific research facility to include the role of academic leadership, facility managers, specialised facility staff and the journey to become a facility manager
(3)Managing finances within a core facility to include developing long-term sustainable plans, cost recovery, procurement and building business cases
(4)Administrative and systems management including project management tools, health and safety requirements, accreditation requirements, environmental sustainability, and data storage and management
(5)Understanding your customers and developing effective networks to maximise the impact of your facility to include marketing strategies, customer service and engagement and engaging with external networks
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week will include a 1-hour lecture, a 2-hour workshop and 12 hours of self-directed study. A range of resources will be provided on Canvas including tasks to be performed in advance of the lectures or workshops and additional material to supplement the content covered during the taught sessions.
Lectures
Description: Teacher led lecture with discussion points to stimulate interaction
Attendance Record: Yes
Workshops
Description: The workshops will include a range of activities including directed tasks, group discussions with peers and technologists working in the Shared Research Facilities, and computer workshops to develop cost recovery and business plans, and gain hands on experience of using procurement and project management software. The students will visit several Shared Research Facilities during the workshops and engage with the facility technologist or facility managers to discuss different topics for example, engaging with collaborators, implementing levels of accreditation or environmental sustainability plans. The workshops will provide opportunities to work in teams, allow students to learn via peer discussions, interact with technologists working in the Shared Research Facilities and gain formative feedback to advance their learning and develop skills S1-S3.
Attendance record: Yes
Self-directed learning
Description: Independent study will include, background reading, content to supplement taught sessions including short videos and reading and pre-lecture or workshop tasks to include short video and background reading.
Attendance Recorded: No

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be engaged with the activities and technologists or managers working in the Shared Research Facilities throughout the module.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will perform activities during the workshops that are routine tasks performed in core research facilities including developing business and financial plans where formative feedback will be provided. They will also build skills and experience throughout the module to complete the two assessments, (1) evaluating proposals for new facility resources and (2) developing a strategy for a new core scientific research facility, both of which are routine tasks performed by a core facility manager.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the critical evaluation of proposals, developing strategies to apply in the workplace and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.
- Active learning. Students will participate in group activities, workshops and engage with members of the Shared Research Facilities to learn from the experience of staff working in the facilities.
- Digital fluency. Students will participate in workshops to develop cost recovery and financial business plans and gain hands-on experience of using procurement and project management software. This practical experience learning how to use software typically applied in the workplace environment and financial models to build costs recovery plans working towards a sustainable business plan will build confidence.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary.
The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessments with compensation between assessments so students must achieve a pass across the module.

Assessment 1 (1000 words, 40% overall mark)
In the first assessment students will produce a written report to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources in a format that would be suitable for submission in a research proposal. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives M1-M2 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving) and S2 (communication).

Assessment 2 (10 minute presentation, 10% overall mark)
In the second assessment students will develop a strategy to launch a new core scientific research facility. They will provide a 10-minute individual presentation to outline their strategy. This assessment directly links to the learning objective M3-M4 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment).

Assessment 3 (1000 words, 50% overall mark)
In the third assessment students will produce a written report in a format that would be suitable for submission in a research proposal to comprehensively describe their strategy to launch a new scientific core research facility. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives M1-M4 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment).

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on research relevant proposals and develop a strategy to launch a new core scientific research facility.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will evaluate example proposals for new facility resources and develop a strategy for a new core scientific research facility, both of which are tasks routinely performed by a core facility manager.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the critical evaluation of proposals, developing strategies to launch a core research facility and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.
- Active learning. Students will participate in group activities, workshops and engage with members of the Shared Research Facilities to learn from the experience of staff working in the facilities. This experience will be highly valuable in the preparation of assessments.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary.
The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically evaluate the roles and responsibilities of a core scientific research facility and synthesise this knowledge to develop strategies for applying these principles within a workplace setting.
 LO2 Critically analyse the financial requirements of operating a core scientific research facility, and develop a comprehensive financial plan to establish a sustainable business model.
 LO3 Critically evaluate the operational procedures used in core scientific research facilities and apply this analysis to identify and implement appropriate processes within a workplace setting.
 LO4 Analyse the customer base of a typical scientific research facility and develop a strategic plan to build professional networks and enhance the impact of a core facility within a specific research discipline.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Problem-solving skills: developing approaches and strategies that can be applied in their own research discipline/workplace
 S2 Communication skills: working with peers and communicating with managers and staff working in core facilities to achieve learning objectives, presentation skills during assessments
 S3 Team (group) working: collaboration, developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment


Overview

Requirements Overview
Admission requirements are the same as the Advanced Bioscience Techniques and Research Facility Management MSc programme.

We will require BSc degree in Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Engineering, Computer Sciences or related disciplines (e.g. Biochemistry, Medical Engineering...). At least 2.2-degree classification (or equivalent) will be usually required. Considering vocational nature of the programme, any applicants with substantial practical/analytical experience will also be considered on a case by case basis.

The specific process of allocation to the research facilities (1-2 student per each facility) necessitates a decision from the admission committee of the programme before the offer of a place on the programme can be made. The admission committee will include the admission tutor and a representative from LIV-SRF. Depending on the specifics of the allocation, some candidates may be interviewed before the decision on admission is made by the committee.

The minimum English Language requirement for international/EU students is IELTS 6.5 with a minimum of 6.0 in each component, or equivalent.

The module has not been approved for the following reasons:
If the assessments are compensatable they should not be 'must pass,' Must pass means each assessment is mandatory and therefore not compensatable. You can have a combination of mandatory and non-mandatory assessments if you feel that an assessment is must pass.

 LO1 Critically evaluate the roles and responsibilities of a core scientific research facility and synthesise this knowledge to develop strategies for applying these principles within a workplace setting.
 LO2 Critically analyse the financial requirements of operating a core scientific research facility, and develop a comprehensive financial plan to establish a sustainable business model.
 LO3 Critically evaluate the operational procedures used in core scientific research facilities and apply this analysis to identify and implement appropriate processes within a workplace setting.
 LO4 Analyse the customer base of a typical scientific research facility and develop a strategic plan to build professional networks and enhance the impact of a core facility within a specific research discipline.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Problem-solving skills: developing approaches and strategies that can be applied in their own research discipline/workplace
 S2 Communication skills: working with peers and communicating with managers and staff working in core facilities to achieve learning objectives, presentation skills during assessments
 S3 Team (group) working: collaboration, developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment


Overview

Requirements Overview
Admission requirements are the same as the Advanced Bioscience Techniques and Research Facility Management MSc programme.

We will require BSc degree in Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Engineering, Computer Sciences or related disciplines (e.g. Biochemistry, Medical Engineering...). At least 2.2-degree classification (or equivalent) will be usually required. Considering vocational nature of the programme, any applicants with substantial practical/analytical experience will also be considered on a case by case basis.

The specific process of allocation to the research facilities (1-2 student per each facility) necessitates a decision from the admission committee of the programme before the offer of a place on the programme can be made. The admission committee will include the admission tutor and a representative from LIV-SRF. Depending on the specifics of the allocation, some candidates may be interviewed before the decision on admission is made by the committee.

The minimum English Language requirement for international/EU students is IELTS 6.5 with a minimum of 6.0 in each component, or equivalent.

Rationale
This module has been developed as part of the new Msc in Advanced Bioscience Techniques and research facility management

BIOS772
Notes
The module will run in the second semester of the MSc Advanced Bioscience Techniques and Research Facility Management programme. All students enrolled on the MSc programme will be required to complete the module. To develop the module a workshop was held including the module coordinator, programme lead, the module teaching staff and members (academic leads and facility managers) representing the range of Shared Research Facilities at the University of Liverpool. The workshop provided a platform to exchange ideas on module content, modes of delivery and assessments methods and criteria that were developed into the module syllabus and specifications by the module coordinator and teaching team.

Overview

Overview
This MSc Module Core Facility Operation and Management Module will introduce students to a multitude of different aspects of running a core scientific facility including the operation and management of a core facility, the roles and responsibilities of the team members, management of finances, understanding your customers and developing networks. Students will undertake a series of lectures, tutorials, workshops including visits and tours of the research facilities and self-directed study and complete two assessments, one to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources and the second to develop a proposal for a new core facility.
Educational Aims
To provide students with the opportunity to apply directed and independent learning to develop a holistic understanding of the role and operation of a core research facility that can be applied in their own scientific discipline and/or workplace.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The 15-credit MSc Core Facility Operation and Management Module will introduce students to a multitude of different aspects of running a core scientific facility including the operation and management of a core facility, the roles and responsibilities of the team members, management of finances, and understanding your customers and developing networks. Students will undertake a series of lectures, tutorials, workshops including visits and tours of the Liverpool shared research facilities and self-directed study to complete the module. Students will complete two assessments (1) to produce a written report to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources and (2) to produce a written report and delivery a presentation to develop a new core facility. The module will enable students to develop an understanding of the operation and management of a core research facility and provide students with an opportunity to present their work in oral and written formats. The module takes place during the second semester.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will be delivered by a combination of lectures, workshops and self-directed learning supported by resources provided on Canvas. The syllabus will include the following elements:
(1)Introduction to core scientific facility and operation including the University of Liverpool Shared Research Facilities, University of Liverpool and UKRI strategies and implications for scientific research facilities
(2)Roles and responsibilities within a core scientific research facility to include the role of academic leadership, facility managers, specialised facility staff and the journey to become a facility manager
(3)Managing finances within a core facility to include developing long-term sustainable plans, cost recovery, procurement and building business cases
(4)Administrative and systems management including project management tools, health and safety requirements, accreditation requirements, environmental sustainability, and data storage and management
(5)Understanding your customers and developing effective networks to maximise the impact of your facility to include marketing strategies, customer service and engagement and engaging with external networks
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week will include a 1-hour lecture, a 2-hour workshop and 12 hours of self-directed study. A range of resources will be provided on Canvas including tasks to be performed in advance of the lectures or workshops and additional material to supplement the content covered during the taught sessions.
Lectures
Description: Teacher led lecture with discussion points to stimulate interaction
Attendance Record: Yes
Workshops
Description: The workshops will include a range of activities including directed tasks, group discussions with peers and technologists working in the Shared Research Facilities, and computer workshops to develop cost recovery and business plans, and gain hands on experience of using procurement and project management software. The students will visit several Shared Research Facilities during the workshops and engage with the facility technologist or facility managers to discuss different topics for example, engaging with collaborators, implementing levels of accreditation or environmental sustainability plans. The workshops will provide opportunities to work in teams, allow students to learn via peer discussions, interact with technologists working in the Shared Research Facilities and gain formative feedback to advance their learning and develop skills S1-S3.
Attendance record: Yes
Self-directed learning
Description: Independent study will include, background reading, content to supplement taught sessions including short videos and reading and pre-lecture or workshop tasks to include short video and background reading.
Attendance Recorded: No

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be engaged with the activities and technologists or managers working in the Shared Research Facilities throughout the module.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will perform activities during the workshops that are routine tasks performed in core research facilities including developing business and financial plans where formative feedback will be provided. They will also build skills and experience throughout the module to complete the two assessments, (1) evaluating proposals for new facility resources and (2) developing a strategy for a new core scientific research facility, both of which are routine tasks performed by a core facility manager.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the critical evaluation of proposals, developing strategies to apply in the workplace and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.
- Active learning. Students will participate in group activities, workshops and engage with members of the Shared Research Facilities to learn from the experience of staff working in the facilities.
- Digital fluency. Students will participate in workshops to develop cost recovery and financial business plans and gain hands-on experience of using procurement and project management software. This practical experience learning how to use software typically applied in the workplace environment and financial models to build costs recovery plans working towards a sustainable business plan will build confidence.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary.
The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessments with compensation between assessments so students must achieve a pass across the module.

Assessment 1 (1000 words, 40% overall mark)
In the first assessment students will produce a written report to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources in a format that would be suitable for submission in a research proposal. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives M1-M2 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving) and S2 (communication).

Assessment 2 (10 minute presentation, 10% overall mark)
In the second assessment students will develop a strategy to launch a new core scientific research facility. They will provide a 10-minute individual presentation to outline their strategy. This assessment directly links to the learning objective M3-M4 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment).

Assessment 3 (1000 words, 50% overall mark)
In the third assessment students will produce a written report in a format that would be suitable for submission in a research proposal to comprehensively describe their strategy to launch a new scientific core research facility. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives M1-M4 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment).

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on research relevant proposals and develop a strategy to launch a new core scientific research facility.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will evaluate example proposals for new facility resources and develop a strategy for a new core scientific research facility, both of which are tasks routinely performed by a core facility manager.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the critical evaluation of proposals, developing strategies to launch a core research facility and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.
- Active learning. Students will participate in group activities, workshops and engage with members of the Shared Research Facilities to learn from the experience of staff working in the facilities. This experience will be highly valuable in the preparation of assessments.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary.
The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Rationale
This module has been developed as part of the new Msc in Advanced Bioscience Techniques and research facility management

Admin

Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Replace Instances with Code
BIOS772
Notes
The module will run in the second semester of the MSc Advanced Bioscience Techniques and Research Facility Management programme. All students enrolled on the MSc programme will be required to complete the module. To develop the module a workshop was held including the module coordinator, programme lead, the module teaching staff and members (academic leads and facility managers) representing the range of Shared Research Facilities at the University of Liverpool. The workshop provided a platform to exchange ideas on module content, modes of delivery and assessments methods and criteria that were developed into the module syllabus and specifications by the module coordinator and teaching team.

Overview

Overview
This MSc Module Core Facility Operation and Management Module will introduce students to a multitude of different aspects of running a core scientific facility including the operation and management of a core facility, the roles and responsibilities of the team members, management of finances, understanding your customers and developing networks. Students will undertake a series of lectures, tutorials, workshops including visits and tours of the research facilities and self-directed study and complete two assessments, one to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources and the second to develop a proposal for a new core facility.
Educational Aims
To provide students with the opportunity to apply directed and independent learning to develop a holistic understanding of the role and operation of a core research facility that can be applied in their own scientific discipline and/or workplace.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The 15-credit MSc Core Facility Operation and Management Module will introduce students to a multitude of different aspects of running a core scientific facility including the operation and management of a core facility, the roles and responsibilities of the team members, management of finances, and understanding your customers and developing networks. Students will undertake a series of lectures, tutorials, workshops including visits and tours of the Liverpool shared research facilities and self-directed study to complete the module. Students will complete two assessments (1) to produce a written report to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources and (2) to produce a written report and delivery a presentation to develop a new core facility. The module will enable students to develop an understanding of the operation and management of a core research facility and provide students with an opportunity to present their work in oral and written formats. The module takes place during the second semester.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will be delivered by a combination of lectures, workshops and self-directed learning supported by resources provided on Canvas. The syllabus will include the following elements:
(1)Introduction to core scientific facility and operation including the University of Liverpool Shared Research Facilities, University of Liverpool and UKRI strategies and implications for scientific research facilities
(2)Roles and responsibilities within a core scientific research facility to include the role of academic leadership, facility managers, specialised facility staff and the journey to become a facility manager
(3)Managing finances within a core facility to include developing long-term sustainable plans, cost recovery, procurement and building business cases
(4)Administrative and systems management including project management tools, health and safety requirements, accreditation requirements, environmental sustainability, and data storage and management
(5)Understanding your customers and developing effective networks to maximise the impact of your facility to include marketing strategies, customer service and engagement and engaging with external networks
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week will include a 1-hour lecture, a 2-hour workshop and 12 hours of self-directed study. A range of resources will be provided on Canvas including tasks to be performed in advance of the lectures or workshops and additional material to supplement the content covered during the taught sessions.
Lectures
Description: Teacher led lecture with discussion points to stimulate interaction
Attendance Record: Yes
Workshops
Description: The workshops will include a range of activities including directed tasks, group discussions with peers and technologists working in the Shared Research Facilities, and computer workshops to develop cost recovery and business plans, and gain hands on experience of using procurement and project management software. The students will visit several Shared Research Facilities during the workshops and engage with the facility technologist or facility managers to discuss different topics for example, engaging with collaborators, implementing levels of accreditation or environmental sustainability plans. The workshops will provide opportunities to work in teams, allow students to learn via peer discussions, interact with technologists working in the Shared Research Facilities and gain formative feedback to advance their learning and develop skills S1-S3.
Attendance record: Yes
Self-directed learning
Description: Independent study will include, background reading, content to supplement taught sessions including short videos and reading and pre-lecture or workshop tasks to include short video and background reading.
Attendance Recorded: No

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be engaged with the activities and technologists or managers working in the Shared Research Facilities throughout the module.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will perform activities during the workshops that are routine tasks performed in core research facilities including developing business and financial plans where formative feedback will be provided. They will also build skills and experience throughout the module to complete the two assessments, (1) evaluating proposals for new facility resources and (2) developing a strategy for a new core scientific research facility, both of which are routine tasks performed by a core facility manager.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the critical evaluation of proposals, developing strategies to apply in the workplace and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.
- Active learning. Students will participate in group activities, workshops and engage with members of the Shared Research Facilities to learn from the experience of staff working in the facilities.
- Digital fluency. Students will participate in workshops to develop cost recovery and financial business plans and gain hands-on experience of using procurement and project management software. This practical experience learning how to use software typically applied in the workplace environment and financial models to build costs recovery plans working towards a sustainable business plan will build confidence.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary.
The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessments with compensation between assessments so students must achieve a pass across the module.

Assessment 1 (1000 words, 40% overall mark)
In the first assessment students will produce a written report to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources in a format that would be suitable for submission in a research proposal. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives M1-M2 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving) and S2 (communication).

Assessment 2 (10 minute presentation, 10% overall mark)
In the second assessment students will develop a strategy to launch a new core scientific research facility. They will provide a 10-minute individual presentation to outline their strategy. This assessment directly links to the learning objective M3-M4 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment).

Assessment 3 (1000 words, 50% overall mark)
In the third assessment students will produce a written report in a format that would be suitable for submission in a research proposal to comprehensively describe their strategy to launch a new scientific core research facility. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives M1-M4 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment).

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on research relevant proposals and develop a strategy to launch a new core scientific research facility.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will evaluate example proposals for new facility resources and develop a strategy for a new core scientific research facility, both of which are tasks routinely performed by a core facility manager.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the critical evaluation of proposals, developing strategies to launch a core research facility and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.
- Active learning. Students will participate in group activities, workshops and engage with members of the Shared Research Facilities to learn from the experience of staff working in the facilities. This experience will be highly valuable in the preparation of assessments.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary.
The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Deliveries

 LocationPeriodMode 
 
Liverpool campus

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically evaluate the roles and responsibilities of a core scientific research facility and synthesise this knowledge to develop strategies for applying these principles within a workplace setting.
 LO2 Critically analyse the financial requirements of operating a core scientific research facility, and develop a comprehensive financial plan to establish a sustainable business model.
 LO3 Critically evaluate the operational procedures used in core scientific research facilities and apply this analysis to identify and implement appropriate processes within a workplace setting.
 LO4 Analyse the customer base of a typical scientific research facility and develop a strategic plan to build professional networks and enhance the impact of a core facility within a specific research discipline.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Problem-solving skills: developing approaches and strategies that can be applied in their own research discipline/workplace
 S2 Communication skills: working with peers and communicating with managers and staff working in core facilities to achieve learning objectives, presentation skills during assessments
 S3 Team (group) working: collaboration, developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment


Overview

Requirements Overview
Admission requirements are the same as the Advanced Bioscience Techniques and Research Facility Management MSc programme.

We will require BSc degree in Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Engineering, Computer Sciences or related disciplines (e.g. Biochemistry, Medical Engineering...). At least 2.2-degree classification (or equivalent) will be usually required. Considering vocational nature of the programme, any applicants with substantial practical/analytical experience will also be considered on a case by case basis.

The specific process of allocation to the research facilities (1-2 student per each facility) necessitates a decision from the admission committee of the programme before the offer of a place on the programme can be made. The admission committee will include the admission tutor and a representative from LIV-SRF. Depending on the specifics of the allocation, some candidates may be interviewed before the decision on admission is made by the committee.

The minimum English Language requirement for international/EU students is IELTS 6.5 with a minimum of 6.0 in each component, or equivalent.

The module will be assessed via three assessments with compensation between assessments so students must achieve a pass across the module.

Assessment 1 (1000 words, 40% overall mark)
In the first assessment students will produce a written report to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources in a format that would be suitable for submission in a research proposal. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives M1-M2 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving) and S2 (communication).

Assessment 2 (10 minute presentation, 10% overall mark)
In the second assessment students will develop a strategy to launch a new core scientific research facility. They will provide a 10-minute individual presentation to outline their strategy. This assessment directly links to the learning objective M3-M4 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment).

Assessment 3 (1000 words, 50% overall mark)
In the third assessment students will produce a written report in a format that would be suitable for submission in a research proposal to comprehensively describe their strategy to launch a new scientific core research facility. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives M1-M4 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment).

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on research relevant proposals and develop a strategy to launch a new core scientific research facility.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will evaluate example proposals for new facility resources and develop a strategy for a new core scientific research facility, both of which are tasks routinely performed by a core facility manager.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the critical evaluation of proposals, developing strategies to launch a core research facility and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.
- Active learning. Students will participate in group activities, workshops and engage with members of the Shared Research Facilities to learn from the experience of staff working in the facilities. This experience will be highly valuable in the preparation of assessments.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary.
The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcome 
 LO1 Critically evaluate the roles and responsibilities of a core scientific research facility and synthesise this knowledge to develop strategies for applying these principles within a workplace setting.
 LO2 Critically analyse the financial requirements of operating a core scientific research facility, and develop a comprehensive financial plan to establish a sustainable business model.
 LO3 Critically evaluate the operational procedures used in core scientific research facilities and apply this analysis to identify and implement appropriate processes within a workplace setting.
 LO4 Analyse the customer base of a typical scientific research facility and develop a strategic plan to build professional networks and enhance the impact of a core facility within a specific research discipline.
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcome 
 S1 Problem-solving skills: developing approaches and strategies that can be applied in their own research discipline/workplace
 S2 Communication skills: working with peers and communicating with managers and staff working in core facilities to achieve learning objectives, presentation skills during assessments
 S3 Team (group) working: collaboration, developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment


Overview

Requirements Overview
Admission requirements are the same as the Advanced Bioscience Techniques and Research Facility Management MSc programme.

We will require BSc degree in Biology, Chemistry, Physics, Engineering, Computer Sciences or related disciplines (e.g. Biochemistry, Medical Engineering...). At least 2.2-degree classification (or equivalent) will be usually required. Considering vocational nature of the programme, any applicants with substantial practical/analytical experience will also be considered on a case by case basis.

The specific process of allocation to the research facilities (1-2 student per each facility) necessitates a decision from the admission committee of the programme before the offer of a place on the programme can be made. The admission committee will include the admission tutor and a representative from LIV-SRF. Depending on the specifics of the allocation, some candidates may be interviewed before the decision on admission is made by the committee.

The minimum English Language requirement for international/EU students is IELTS 6.5 with a minimum of 6.0 in each component, or equivalent.

Rationale
This module has been developed as part of the new Msc in Advanced Bioscience Techniques and research facility management

Notes
The module will run in the second semester of the MSc Advanced Bioscience Techniques and Research Facility Management programme. All students enrolled on the MSc programme will be required to complete the module. To develop the module a workshop was held including the module coordinator, programme lead, the module teaching staff and members (academic leads and facility managers) representing the range of Shared Research Facilities at the University of Liverpool. The workshop provided a platform to exchange ideas on module content, modes of delivery and assessments methods and criteria that were developed into the module syllabus and specifications by the module coordinator and teaching team.

Overview

Overview
This MSc Module Core Facility Operation and Management Module will introduce students to a multitude of different aspects of running a core scientific facility including the operation and management of a core facility, the roles and responsibilities of the team members, management of finances, understanding your customers and developing networks. Students will undertake a series of lectures, tutorials, workshops including visits and tours of the research facilities and self-directed study and complete two assessments, one to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources and the second to develop a proposal for a new core facility.
Educational Aims
To provide students with the opportunity to apply directed and independent learning to develop a holistic understanding of the role and operation of a core research facility that can be applied in their own scientific discipline and/or workplace.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The 15-credit MSc Core Facility Operation and Management Module will introduce students to a multitude of different aspects of running a core scientific facility including the operation and management of a core facility, the roles and responsibilities of the team members, management of finances, and understanding your customers and developing networks. Students will undertake a series of lectures, tutorials, workshops including visits and tours of the Liverpool shared research facilities and self-directed study to complete the module. Students will complete two assessments (1) to produce a written report to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources and (2) to produce a written report and delivery a presentation to develop a new core facility. The module will enable students to develop an understanding of the operation and management of a core research facility and provide students with an opportunity to present their work in oral and written formats. The module takes place during the second semester.
Outline Syllabus
The syllabus will be delivered by a combination of lectures, workshops and self-directed learning supported by resources provided on Canvas. The syllabus will include the following elements:
(1)Introduction to core scientific facility and operation including the University of Liverpool Shared Research Facilities, University of Liverpool and UKRI strategies and implications for scientific research facilities
(2)Roles and responsibilities within a core scientific research facility to include the role of academic leadership, facility managers, specialised facility staff and the journey to become a facility manager
(3)Managing finances within a core facility to include developing long-term sustainable plans, cost recovery, procurement and building business cases
(4)Administrative and systems management including project management tools, health and safety requirements, accreditation requirements, environmental sustainability, and data storage and management
(5)Understanding your customers and developing effective networks to maximise the impact of your facility to include marketing strategies, customer service and engagement and engaging with external networks
Teaching and Learning Methods
A typical week will include a 1-hour lecture, a 2-hour workshop and 12 hours of self-directed study. A range of resources will be provided on Canvas including tasks to be performed in advance of the lectures or workshops and additional material to supplement the content covered during the taught sessions.
Lectures
Description: Teacher led lecture with discussion points to stimulate interaction
Attendance Record: Yes
Workshops
Description: The workshops will include a range of activities including directed tasks, group discussions with peers and technologists working in the Shared Research Facilities, and computer workshops to develop cost recovery and business plans, and gain hands on experience of using procurement and project management software. The students will visit several Shared Research Facilities during the workshops and engage with the facility technologist or facility managers to discuss different topics for example, engaging with collaborators, implementing levels of accreditation or environmental sustainability plans. The workshops will provide opportunities to work in teams, allow students to learn via peer discussions, interact with technologists working in the Shared Research Facilities and gain formative feedback to advance their learning and develop skills S1-S3.
Attendance record: Yes
Self-directed learning
Description: Independent study will include, background reading, content to supplement taught sessions including short videos and reading and pre-lecture or workshop tasks to include short video and background reading.
Attendance Recorded: No

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be engaged with the activities and technologists or managers working in the Shared Research Facilities throughout the module.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will perform activities during the workshops that are routine tasks performed in core research facilities including developing business and financial plans where formative feedback will be provided. They will also build skills and experience throughout the module to complete the two assessments, (1) evaluating proposals for new facility resources and (2) developing a strategy for a new core scientific research facility, both of which are routine tasks performed by a core facility manager.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the critical evaluation of proposals, developing strategies to apply in the workplace and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.
- Active learning. Students will participate in group activities, workshops and engage with members of the Shared Research Facilities to learn from the experience of staff working in the facilities.
- Digital fluency. Students will participate in workshops to develop cost recovery and financial business plans and gain hands-on experience of using procurement and project management software. This practical experience learning how to use software typically applied in the workplace environment and financial models to build costs recovery plans working towards a sustainable business plan will build confidence.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary.
The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed via three assessments with compensation between assessments so students must achieve a pass across the module.

Assessment 1 (1000 words, 40% overall mark)
In the first assessment students will produce a written report to critically evaluate proposals for new facility resources in a format that would be suitable for submission in a research proposal. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives M1-M2 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving) and S2 (communication).

Assessment 2 (10 minute presentation, 10% overall mark)
In the second assessment students will develop a strategy to launch a new core scientific research facility. They will provide a 10-minute individual presentation to outline their strategy. This assessment directly links to the learning objective M3-M4 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment).

Assessment 3 (1000 words, 50% overall mark)
In the third assessment students will produce a written report in a format that would be suitable for submission in a research proposal to comprehensively describe their strategy to launch a new scientific core research facility. This assessment directly links to the learning objectives M1-M4 and supports the development of skills S1 (problem-solving), S2 (communication) and S3 (developing communication skills that can be transferred into the working environment).

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given for each assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission. Pass mark is 50.

Liverpool Curriculum Framework addressed:
- Research-connected teaching. Students will be assessed on research relevant proposals and develop a strategy to launch a new core scientific research facility.
- Authentic Assessment. Students will evaluate example proposals for new facility resources and develop a strategy for a new core scientific research facility, both of which are tasks routinely performed by a core facility manager.
- Confidence. Students will develop skills that are routinely applied in the workplace environment including the critical evaluation of proposals, developing strategies to launch a core research facility and effective communication of their work. Developing workplace relevant skills will build confidence in students to demonstrate their employability and prepare students for the workplace environment.
- Active learning. Students will participate in group activities, workshops and engage with members of the Shared Research Facilities to learn from the experience of staff working in the facilities. This experience will be highly valuable in the preparation of assessments.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary.
The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

The module has not been approved for the following reasons:
The module has not been approved for the following reasons:
If the assessments are compensatable they should not be 'must pass,' Must pass means each assessment is mandatory and therefore not compensatable. You can have a combination of mandatory and non-mandatory assessments if you feel that an assessment is must pass.
